\\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: some insight into the reversal in the us-euro area interest rate differential could be derived from the breakdown of bond yields into the short-term rate expectations component and the term premia component.\n                '}]

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: members also reiterated that monetary policy should continue to be based on the established elements of the reaction function.\n                '}]

Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the risks to inflation remained twofold.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence simply states that there are risks to inflation, but does not indicate the direction or magnitude of the risks, making it a neutral statement."

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: overall, financial conditions remained supportive of the economic expansion, although the repricing in some financial market segments, in particular in foreign exchange markets and the bond markets, had led to some deterioration since the previous meeting.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:51:21,056 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence describes the current financial conditions as supportive of economic expansion, but also notes some deterioration, indicating a balanced view without a clear hawkish or dovish tone."
}

demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: there was thus broad agreement among members that a strong policy response was required, which was best achieved by a comprehensive package of measures that exploited the synergies and complementarities between its different components.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies a strong policy response is needed, suggesting a hawkish stance as the ECB is likely to take contractionary measures to address economic concerns."
}

secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central "justification": "The sentence suggests that a recession, which is a slowdown in economic growth, is likely, and this would mitigate inflationary pressures, implying that the ECB may want to adopt a more accommodative monetary policy stance."

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: second, investors did not foresee a scenario in which inflation would return to below-target levels.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that investors expect inflation to remain above target levels, which may lead the ECB to take measures to control inflation, such as increasing interest rates."

"Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: second, there was a need to signal that any adjustments to the key ecb interest rates would take place ”some time after the end of the governing council’s net purchases under the app”.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that interest rate adjustments will occur after the end of the net purchases under the asset purchase program, suggesting a potential tightening of monetary policy."
}

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: compared with december expectations, risks to the growth outlook had become more balanced.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a shift towards a more balanced growth outlook, neither leaning towards a dovish nor hawkish stance, hence neutral."

to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: based on leading indicators, no immediate recovery was in sight.\n                '}]

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: external financing flows to euro area nfcs had strengthened overall in the fourth quarter of 2016, driven by robust developments in bank lending and market-based financing in october and november.\n                '}]

fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: against this background, members assessed the data that had become available since the september monetary policy meeting in accordance with the three main elements of the “reaction function” that the governing council had communicated earlier in the year.\n                '}]

demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it was expected that domestic demand would continue to be the main factor driving growth in the euro area, while exports showed signs of less dynamism.\n                '}]
